data.text: Exercises to keep the muscles around joints strong (I had tendinitis in both shoulders and both knees so my doctor wrote to my pt what I should do and, more important, what I shouldn‚Äôt do). During trips: I stretch the majority of muscles. I always carry ant inflammatory sprays and/or cream; I don‚Äôt push myself: if I start feeling a slightly pain in any joints, I take a day off, let the body rest.
data.author: Carol Teramoto

data.text: Stretching helped for me, before, during, and especially after exercise. Other prep would be to work up to longer mileages. Tendons take time to adjust to higher and prolonged workloads. More time than muscles do. Also footwear. I am prone to Achilles tendonitis, and any footwear (boots especially) the press in above my heel can bring this on. The only boots I can wear now have a neoprene upper section.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text: I JUST read about "heel cup height" and cycling injuries. It seems the height of the back of the shoe ("heel cup") can cause problems. Try shoes with a lower cup, or (worst case scenario) take a knife to the top of the heel of the shoe
data.author: Chris Ware

data.text: Higher cadence. Drop one gear. You‚Äôre working too hard
data.author: Tim Attwood

data.text: If you do "big miles" over a short period of time and this is not what you normally do then don't be surprised when your body doesn't like it. Instead of high mileage over 3 days space it out over a week and you may not have caused the tendinitis. Sorry this doesn't help you now. But we must train the way we intend to ride.
data.author: Tony Ball

data.text: Absolutely right. Stress must come progressively.
data.author: John Gero

data.text: ride in lower gears. R.I.C.E. = rest, ice, compression, elevation. self-massage before and after a ride, using some sort of healing balm. i use both tiger balm and diclofenac-based voltarol. aspirin or ibuprofin. good luck! i have had tendon problems for decades: once it flares up, i take it real easy. bad timing sometimes.... (like RIGHT NOW!) but i find it is not much fun to ride when the very acting of pushing the pedals causes pain....
data.author: Miko Sloper

data.text: My Physio suggested lowering my seat a bit and/or move cleat back a bit to take calf muscle out of the equation some. Worked for me.
data.author: Scott Lawson

data.text: Work up to it gradually and get your technique right. All the push and pressure should be on the big muscles and joints: hip and thigh, not knee or ankle, which should be kept free and loose.
data.author: Jack Robins

data.text: 100%. Shifting your cleats back can help with engaging your bigger upper leg muscles too.
data.author: Rob Walker

data.text: Some good suggestions above. Worst case when it happens - carry KT straps. Had to do this myself a few times
data.author: Rob Walker

data.text: I don't use cleats. I hate them. I'm worried about my feet getting stuck in them. I use a cage: easy to pull the feet out.
data.author: Jack Robins

data.text: Bike fit - long distance riding generally requires a lower seat height than 'racing'
data.author: Joel Nicholson

data.text: Lots of well meant suggestions here but any tendon has only one way to prevent injury and only one way to cure it - stretching. Each and every day after quick warmup and up to several times a day on long bike rides. Had it everywhere, ellbows, hands kneecap, knee side, achilles. Stretching is what makes it go away aftera few days or weeks if its bad, and if you keep it up it wont come back
data.author: Hajo Reuter

data.text: rest and stretching are good ways to treat it but stretching, easing up to longer distances and good technique are the best ways to prevent it
data.author: Jack Robins

data.text: exactly my point!
data.author: Hajo Reuter

data.text: Make sure your setup is correct. Seat not too high. The foot should be flat on the stroke bottom. Knees in a relaxed position over feet. Otherwise calf stretching is a must, a tight achilles is a response to tight calves and hammies. And massage guns can be excellent for areas that usually get low blood flow or are tough to stretch.
data.author: Michael Manning

data.text: KT tape works wonders. You can look up on YouTube the taping instructions. I rode the Southern Tier in 2018. Had Achilles tendinitis pretty bad by the time we made El Paso. Started KT taping in El Paso. Wore it every day. By the time we arrived St. Augustine six weeks later, my Achilles was back to normal.

data.text: You should address cramping risk every day. In other words take an electrolyte with salt before and after your days ride. It will prevent the buildup of lactic acid that contributes to cramping and injuries.
